text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives in a small apartment on the 30th floor of a high-rise building.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator to the 15th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining 15 floors to his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor.

Why does he do this? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out why this man takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor on rainy days.
Let me break this down step by step.
First, let's understand his regular routine.
Every morning, he takes the elevator down from the 30th floor to the ground floor (which is floor 1) to go to work.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator up to the 15th floor and then walks up the remaining 15 floors to his apartment on the 30th floor.
So, in the evening, he's saving himself some time by taking the elevator part of the way and walking the rest.
That makes sense because walking 15 floors might take some time, especially if he's in a hurry or if it's tiring.
Now, on rainy days, he changes his routine.
Instead of taking the elevator up to the 15th floor and walking, he takes the elevator all the way up to the 30th floor.
Why would he do that? Let's think about the possible reasons.
One possibility is that on rainy days, walking up the stairs is more uncomfortable or dangerous.
Maybe the stairs get slippery when it's raining, making it harder to walk up 15 floors.
That could explain why he takes the elevator instead.
Safety is a big concern, especially if the building isn't equipped with non-slip staircases or if the weather is bad.
Another angle is the time factor.

If it's raining heavily, maybe the elevator is faster because it's moving vertically, whereas walking up 15 floors could be time-consuming and inconvenient, especially if he's in a hurry to get to his apartment after work.
Alternatively, perhaps the man has a physical condition that makes climbing stairs difficult, especially in the rain.
Walking up 15 floors might be strenuous for him, so taking the elevator is more comfortable.
I should also consider the building's infrastructure.
Maybe the stairs on higher floors are less maintained or have issues when it's raining.
So, taking the elevator avoids any potential problems with the stairs.
But the most straightforward reason seems to be safety.
Rainy days can make surfaces slippery, and walking up 15 floors on wet stairs is risky.
By taking the elevator all the way, he avoids the hazard and ensures his safety.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator up to the 30th floor on rainy days because walking up the stairs would be unsafe due to the rain making the stairs slippery.

</think>

The man takes the elevator all the way up on rainy days because walking up the stairs would be unsafe.
The rain makes the stairs slippery, posing a risk of slipping or falling.
By using the elevator, he ensures his safety and avoids potential hazards.
